channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: How Trump's sweeping new travel ban may affect the many nations it targets
item.description: President Trump announces a sweeping travel ban on citizens from 12 countries, with restrictions on seven others -- evoking the "Muslim ban" Trump introduced during his first term.

item.title: Volunteers are helping save climate data — which teachers rely on — before it's lost
item.description: As the Trump administration removes climate-related data and tools from agency websites, teachers are left scrambling to fix lesson plans. But, a volunteer effort is archiving much of the lost data.

item.title: Here to Help: A man's decades-long history with Habitat for Humanity
item.description: Gerard Van de Werken is a volunteer with Habitat for Humanity Austin, a non-profit housing organization. For our series, Here to Help, he discusses his decades-long history with the organization.

item.title: Fans drive huge Nintendo Switch 2 launch; others play the waiting game
item.description: Criticized for its high cost but still selling out nearly everywhere, Nintendo's sequel to their popular Switch console releases as a trade war squeezes the video game industry.

item.title: Trump's tariffs could cut deficit by $2.8 trillion over next decade — with caveats
item.description: Forecasters at the Congressional Budget Office say President Trump's tariffs could shave $2.8 trillion off the federal debt if they remain in place for a decade. That's a big if.

item.title: New York Yankees slugger Aaron Judge is closing in on a .400 batting average
item.description: Aaron Judge of the New York Yankees has had a great season and is closing in on one of baseball's rarest batting milestones: breaking .400. The last player to do it was Ted Williams in 1941.

item.title: Air traffic overhaul obstacles
item.description: The fragile state of the U.S. air traffic control system was easy to see during the recent outages in Newark. But it will be a lot harder to make up for decades of underinvestment and other mistakes.

item.title: 'She Who Dared,' an opera about women in the civil rights movement, opens in Chicago
item.description: A new opera tells the story of the Black women who organized in Alabama leading up to the Montgomery bus boycott.

item.title: A single mother of eight in Gaza is running out of ways to cope
item.description: A single mother in Gaza describes what hunger looks like for her and her eight children under Israeli restrictions on aid.

item.title: Hungry hungry elephant raids grocery store and hardly hurts a fly
item.description: When a massive elephant entered a small grocery shore in Thailand in search of snacks, chaos did not ensue.
